could not have been built up in stages by natural selection. Among his most
influential examples is a discussion of devices that some bacteria use for mo-
tion, flagella. He contrasts the bacterial flagellum with a different motor,
used by other cells, the cilium. “In 1973 it was discovered that some bacteria
swim by rotating their flagella. So the bacterial flagellum acts as a rotary
propeller—in contrast to the cilium, which acts more like an oar.”*Both fla-
gella and cilia are intricate
